attributes.alt: Book cover for First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood. The cover shows a mother and father standing together in a desert holding a baby.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What different family members do you hear about in the story?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Have children describe the activity in the picture.
Challenge children to identify the different  family members they see in the pictures.
How many families can you find in that book? How many people are in the family?
Who in your family can you pretend to be? How will you act?
How can you sort the people in your family into different groups?
Who in your family can you draw?
What materials can you use to make little figures of the people in your family?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to make a house for the family you made?

attributes.alt: Book cover for First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood. The cover shows a mother and father standing together in a desert holding a baby.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Help children use their imaginations to discuss what the families are doing in the picture.
Guide children to imagine what it might be like to do the same activities.
Can you find a family that is celebrating a special day?
Can you try to make someone laugh?
Can you count how many brothers and sisters the children in your group have?
What does your family like to do for fun? Can you draw a picture  that shows this?
Can you make tiny versions of some of your family’s favorite foods?
Find the letters that spell the name of one person in your family.
Use your imagination to build a fun house for your family.

attributes.alt: Book cover for First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood. The cover shows a mother and father standing together in a desert holding a baby.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What different family members do you hear about in the story?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Work with children to make individual books about what makes their families special.
Share their books with classmates and family members.
How is the family in that book different from your family?
Can you show me what you could do to make a baby laugh?
Can you count the number of people in your family?
Draw a picture of a really big family. Who will you include?
Can you color and decorate your picture of the big family you drew?
Can you find the letter that makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you build something fun that your family could ride around in?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood, illustrated by Jonathan Nelson. attributes.alt:
A chart with the title My Family and Me, showing six different images of families together.
 The images include:
•   A large family gathered together at the table with many generations present.
•   A mother, brother, and sister reading.
•   Grandparents and a grandchild playing with a dog.
•   A father and two brothers playing soccer.
•   An aunt, uncle, and cousins eating outside.
•   Two adults and two girls playing a board game.
Book cover for First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood. The cover shows a mother and father standing together in a desert holding a baby.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about families, act out some things that families do together, and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Look at and talk about picture cards of animals.
Sort the picture cards that show animals in the same family and pictures that show animals that are not in the same family.
What animal families do you know?
Pretend you are your favorite animal. Show how you walk.
How many different animal families do you know?
Draw a picture of your favorite animal with its family.
What crayons would you use to color your picture of the animal family?
What letter is at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to make a family of your favorite animals? Which one is the biggest?

attributes.alt: Book cover for First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood. The cover shows a mother and father standing together in a desert holding a baby.

elements.text: Use Circle Time for a family fingerplay and to introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by rereading the book and asking,
How do family members show that they care about each other?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Identify unique characteristics in themselves, classmates, and children from other cultures.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
“What is the most important thing that family members can do for each other?”
Can you imagine what it would be like to be the brother or sister of a character in your book?
Pretend it’s your turn to make dinner. What will you make?
Who is the tallest person in your family?
Tell me a story about something funny that happened in your family. Can you draw a picture to go with your story?
Draw a picture of yourself doing your favorite activity with your family. How will you color it?
What is the first letter of the word
Can you use blocks to build a house for a pet?
